awd_titl_txt: Conference:  LabPhon 15 - Speech Dynamics and Phonological Representation
awd_abstract_narration:
Speech sounds form the building blocks of spoken languages.  Sounds are combined into words, but languages have different rules regarding how sounds can be combined. Sometimes sounds change in complicated ways, depending on other sounds in a word. Languages have different patterns for changing sounds as well. Of the roughly 7000 languages remaining in the world, these rules and patterns have been studied in only a handful, and our understanding of why such rules and patterns exist is incomplete. Extending traditional methods of describing and documenting speech sounds, Laboratory Phonology is an approach that incorporates a rich array of experimental methods and interdisciplinary approaches to understanding human speech sounds as the building blocks of language as part of a linguistic, cognitive, and communicative system.

Four of the last five Conferences in Laboratory Phonology (LabPhon) have been hosted outside of the US, and Cornell's Department of Linguistics will bring the conference back to the US, July 13-16, 2016, with the theme of Speech Dynamics and Phonological Representation.  This conference will bring together not only phonologists and phoneticians, but also researchers from other subfields and allied fields including psycholinguists, sociolinguists, clinical linguists, L1 & L2 acquisitionists, computer scientists, cognitive scientists, and neuroscientists and others with an interest in the nature of speech.  These scholars and students from around the world will share recent advances in our understanding of the sound systems of human language. LabPhon15 will focus on increasing the participation of graduate students and early-career scholars in the LabPhon research community, and will strengthen the visibility of outstanding research done by women scholars.

por.por_cntn:
Human speech is integral to every aspect of society. A key international forum for advancing the understanding of human speech is the biennial workshop on Laboratory Phonology (LabPhon), bringing together researchers from around the world taking experimental approaches to the investigation of human speech. The sorts of interdisciplinary collaborations supported by the laboratory phonology community bring increased awareness of the importance of linguistics and human speech to our society.

With the support of an NSF conference award, the 15th workshop on Laboratory Phonology (LabPhon 15) took place at Cornell University July 13-16, 2016. The intellectual aim of the conference was to provide an interactive environment for debate and exploration of ideas related to the theme of Speech Dynamics and Phonological Representation. This theme was selected to bring attention to recent trends in both empirical and theoretical approaches to speech research. The emphasis on dynamics also aimed to encourage researchers to engage in ways of thinking that are more common in biological and physical sciences. An interactive environment for debate and exploration was successfully created by six thematic sessions of talks and six poster sessions over the course of the workshop, which were attended by about 300 participants from 21 countries. These aims were furthered by a total of nine satellite workshops on July 13 and 17th, attended by about 200 conference participants.

The broader impacts of the conference were to increase the participation of graduate students and early-career scholars in the LabPhon research community, and to strengthen the visibility of outstanding research done by women scholars. With the financial support of this award, these broader impacts were successfully achieved. Reduced conference registration fees for graduate students, affordable on-campus lodging, and 19 travel support awards resulted in over 100 graduate students attending the conference. A dinner for graduate students and invited speakers enhanced the quality of the student experience at the conference, and fostered professional and scholarly exchange. Travel awards for invited speakers enabled selection of invited participants to further achieve these goals. Four of the six invited speakers were women, promoting the broader impact of heightening visibility of research done by women scholars. Five of the six invited speakers were early-career scholars, having become academic faculty in the 10 years preceding the conference.

As far as follow-up activities, short and long abstracts of all accepted presentations are archived on the conference website. We also worked closely with the new editor of Laboratory Phonology in its new online only open access format to promote the journal and the close connection between the conference and the journal and all conference participants were strongly encouraged to submit their papers to the journal. We are working together with the organizers of LabPhon16 – to take place in Lisbon, Portugal in June 2018 – to provide support for the organization of this next meeting.
